Michigan Senate committee approves autonomous vehicle legislation The Michigan Senate Committee on Economic Development and International Investment approved a package of bills on Wednesday that would modernize legislation for autonomous vehicles to promote research and testing.Senate Bills 995-998 would update Michigan legislation to legalize autonomous vehicle testing and operation in real-world situations to better enable researchers to enhance the safety and technology needed to get the cars to market.
“Michigan, for much of its history, has been known throughout the world as the home of the automobile, and it is only appropriate that we continue to be a pioneer in the industry,” State Sen. Ken Horn (R-Frankenmuth) said. “Data shows that more than 90 percent of auto accidents are caused because of human error. If we can remain an integral part of the development of technology to reduce these errors, I think it will be a great move for our state.” Horn chairs the committee and sponsored the legislation. The bills allow driverless vehicles on public roads, provided that an operator is present and has the option to control the vehicle manually. The bills also specify parameters for data collection to further enhance safety and technology.The bills also propose the creation of the American Center for Mobility at the abandoned 300-acre Willow Run facility, which would serve as a statewide facility for autonomous vehicle research and development.The bills were sent to the full Senate for consideration.

Michigan Senate Rules at 3.201, quoting the state Constitution at Article IV, Section 26, say a bill can’t be passed until it’s been “printed or reproduced and in possession of the Senate” for at least five days.  According to @barhoom, there will be a special session starting on Tuesday through December. The language of both the rule and the Constitution specify “regular session,” and the only thing I can find about special sessions without working too hard is that no bill may be considered in one unless it’s included in the call, which is easy to do. However, if this one is not in the call, it can’t be passed in the special.  In some places there is a shorter dispensation for special sessions, but if Michigan has one I can’t find it. (This does not mean it doesn’t exist. I have never worked in the Michigan legislature and everyone I know who did is either dead or living in Florida now.)  Since the bill was amended at some point, according to the analysis, it is probably considered a new bill and so has to be in the body’s possession for five days. Also can’t find a definition of whether days is calendar days, business days, session days, or legislative days. These are not always the same—in some states it is up to the body whether a day has started or ended, so you can rip through three or four legislative days in a couple of hours, but the next legislative day might take two weeks to run its course. In most states, a session day is just a calendar day when the chamber (or sometimes either chamber) has a floor session.  So, to cut this short for a change:  If the session starting Tuesday is a special, the bill must be included in the session call to be considered. If it is, it may have to sit around for up to five days of some sort before being voted on. After that it goes over to the House. I have not started to wade through the House rules yet, but I suppose I must sooner or later, as it is beginning to matter. They are likely quite similar on most of these points.  The result is this baby could be on Governor's desk by the first week in October. I have not checked the Constitution to see how many days the governor has to decide what to do, but it seems likely he’ll sign it as soon as he sees it. It therefore seems increasingly probable that the patient will live. Bumping my number way up, but also checking the bill-status system daily from now on. This will cut deeply into my nap time.

Once again one hopes, on the basis of no evidence, that those who wrote and will score this Q understand the words they have used.  Legislation is enacted when the legislature passes a bill and the governor signs it (or it is passed over the governor's veto).  Just passing a bill is not sufficient, nor is an executive order of the governor.  It would not have to be a separate bill, but could be a smallish section of a bit of legislation that gets enacted.   There are very few legislatures still in session, and most of those still sitting are not dealing much with substantive legislation, although a rider tacked onto an emergency budget bill is not out of the question.  The ambiguous, and not at all improbable, case is an item in a budget bill that appropriates money to some agency or university to conduct research on this subject but doesn't explicitly authorize them to turn the vehicles loose for that purpose.   In my view that's still a No, but if compensated sufficiently I could make the opposite case.  Holding at zero, probably unwisely.

First, I have to say that the wording of the question is a little bit tricky. It asks if any US state enact legislation that "allows" AV to operate on its public roads. Therefore, it might exclude those that have already enacted such laws, like CA, but later they enact additional bills that are mere slight amendments. However, for the sake of simplicity I decided to count such situations as resolving the question to "yes". Thinking about how to approach the problem, I find out it all boils down to the probability that any current bill would pass a legislation process and get enacted regardless the state. Therefore, the unit of measurement will not be the state but the bill. So I gathered all AV related bills and they could be found on these URLs:  http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Automated_Driving:_Legislative_and_Regulatory_Action  http://www.ncsl.org/research/transportation/autonomous-vehicles-legislation.aspx#Introduced%202016 However, states that have their legislatures’' sessions closed should not be counted in. Only those are still open, their sessions are on hold due to vacations, or those that have scheduled special sessions in the rest of the year will be considered. Additionally I neglected bills that request studies or mere definitions of VC without clear impact on permissibility on being on the road. This filters out bills and states to only 5 states and 12 bills. After limiting the scope of search, I looked into the factors that would affect the probability of any bill to successfully enacted (merit-based probability). I found a very helpful website that provides a statistical model based on satisfactory number of congressional bills and uses logistics regression that encompasses 18 factors. This is the URL:  https://www.govtrack.us/about/analysis#prognosis/factors I used this model to calculate the overall probability of a bill success regardless time.  Then I looked into each bill and assigned a relevant probability according to the stage where it is currently in (in which house and in which reading round - reading 1, 2 or 3). So bills at 3rd reading in the 2nd house (senate or assembly) have higher probability of passing than bills in 1st or 2nd reading round in the 1st house. This is a time-based probability.  Then I let the model run the calculations to find out the probability of the success of each bill (the probability based on its own merit * the probability of its progress in the senate/assembly houses).  Finally, I calculated the combined probability of any bill get enacted.
